## {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

![](Images/02-1-Burke_Quote.jpg){style="display: block; margin: 0 auto"}

::: notes

Munger kicks off his chapter with a longer version of this quote.

- "Government is a contrivance of human wisdom to provide for human wants. Men have a right that these wants should be provided for by this wisdom" (Edmund Burke, Reflections on the Revolution in France, November 1790).

<br>

**What do you think of this as a definition of "government" or the purpose of "government"?**

- **By these terms, were you a government during our fishing simulation?**

<br>

Burke frames government as a human effort to deliver what we want

- Burke acknowledges that government is not "god-given" or part of the "natural order", it is a device built by us to achieve specific aims

- "contrivance": "the use of skill to bring something about or create something" (OED)

<br>

Importantly, this means that "government" is not impartial, perfect, or fixed in nature

- Governing is really hard.

- It is a human operation run by a community to achieve the goals of that community.

- In the simulation you were doing your best to manage a bunch of interests in the face of great uncertainty!

<br>

Even MORE importantly, this means government is not separate from you.

- It is not a building far away or a special class of people

- It is the confusing name we apply to our community's efforts to solve problems

<br>

We live in a big, complicated country and its functioning well depends on you

- Problem-solving is in your hands

- The "decider" can be anyone, or any group, willing to put in the work 

- If you design a plan that meets the needs of its stakeholders and the conditions on the ground, you can make a difference

- THIS is how our government is designed to work

## {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

::: {.r-fit-text}
**EVERY policy creates winners and losers**
:::

![](Images/02-1-winners.jpg){style="display: block; margin: 0 auto"}

::: notes

Never forget, however, that in real-world problem-solving we play with live ammunition (so to speak)

<br>

Policy designers must NEVER forget that **all policies create winners and losers**.

+ Policy-making is **ALWAYS a choice** and **all choices have consequences**.

<br>

For example, Missouri just raised its minimum wage

- **Who benefits from increases to the minimum wage?**

- **Who pays the costs for those increases?**

- **Is there any way to pay workers more without distributing the costs to society?**

<br>

The same is true with environmental policies

- Take the clean air standards set by the Clean Air Act and the EPA

- **Who benefits from cleaner air?**

- **And who pays the costs for it?**

- **Is there any way to get cleaner air without impacting polluting industries?**

<br>

**Humor me, can we think of any policy or rule in our society whether implemented by government, school, or your employer, that does not impose costs on someone?**

<br>

So, policy is, in essence, a rule or rules adopted by a society to structure behavior.

- All rules impose costs on some and provide benefits to others

- Policy-making is often an exercise in deciding who will pay the costs and who will receive the benefits.

<br>

Ok, so:

1. Government is the label we apply to efforts by human societies to provide for the needs of their own community, and

2. EVERY policy is designed to help someone but inevitably hurts someone else

<br>

Then the question must become, why can't we get the positive ends without the negatives

- **SLIDE**: Let's indulge the libertarian fantasy!

:::

## {background-image="Images/02_1-Cavemen_filtered.png" .center}

:::: {.incremental}

**The Lessons of the Hun-gats**

1. There was never a "state of nature"

2. Survival makes policy a necessity

3. Battles over expertise are unavoidable

4. Policy effectiveness depends on authority

:::
::::

::: notes

**REVEAL 1**: The "state of nature" baseline is probably a stupid one as it never could have existed (not even in this thought experiment)

<br>

Think back to our simulation on the first day of class.

- Most of you were strangers to each other when we played the game and yet your behavior was HEAVILY influenced by:

    - Your individual expectations for how you will do in this class (e.g. is EC valuable or not?),

    - Your individual needs for progress towards your longer-term goals (graduation, grad school, etc)

    - Your desire to be seen by the rest of the group in a particular way (classmates and professor)

    - Your sense of how classrooms in college are supposed to function (e.g. what are the rules of behavior?)

    - Your desire (maybe?) to not exterminate a species

    - and so much more...

<br>

There is no "starting from scratch" anywhere in human societies!

- All new policies are built on top of a mess of established policies and there's no avoiding that

<br>

**REVEAL 2**: Survival odds are maximized by sharing risks and benefits in a community

- Community's require rules to function

- Socialism for the win, eh?

<br>

**REVEAL 3**: Battles over expertise are central to policy-making

- There is no single, perfect standard for evaluating outcomes

- Different perspectives and interests will prefer different standards

<br>

**REVEAL 4**: Policy can only ever be as effective as the authority that compels the behavior, e.g. the birth of religious rules?

<br>

**Is everybody clear on these four "lessons"?**

## What is Policy? {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

<br>

"A definite course or method of action selected (as by a government, institution, group or individual) from among alternatives and in the light of given conditions to guide and usually determine present and future decisions..." (Webster's Third International Dictionary).

::: notes

I don't present this as the "right" or "correct" definition of policy

- Instead, this is a clear definition that takes a position on a few key elements I want us to highlight

<br>

**SLIDE**: Policy is a concrete action

:::

<br>

"A [**definite course or method of action**]{style="color:blue;"} selected (as by a government, institution, group or individual) from among alternatives and in the light of given conditions to guide and usually determine present and future decisions..." (Webster's Third International Dictionary).

::: notes

1) A policy, by definition, is a "definite" "course" or "method" of action

<br>

Think of this like creating a rule of behavior

- Without specificity and clarity the policy cannot hope to change behavior because no one will know what has changed

- e.g. Actor X must do Y

- e.g. Companies investing in new equipment must...

<br>

**SLIDE**: The alternatives
:::



## What is Policy? {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

<br>

"A definite course or method of action selected (as by a government, institution, group or individual) [**from among alternatives**]{style="color:blue;"} and in the light of given conditions to guide and usually determine present and future decisions..." (Webster's Third International Dictionary).

::: notes

This inclusion is excellent but also seems more proscriptive than descriptive

- In other words, I agree that effective policy should be selected from among competing options

- There is NEVER just one answer to an environmental problem

- BUT that seems more like advice to making good policy rather than defining policy

<br>

Either way, I like making it definitional here

- Let's set out to do good work and not just "work"

- The power of defining a concept in action!

<br>

This means I want you to think about ALL policy as choosing one set of rules over another

- Effective problem-solvers MUST be able to explain their choices in the context of the policies not selected

- In other words, you will be expected to have explicitly considered alternatives to your "definite" "course of action" AND be able to explain why you choose the way you did

<br>

**Make sense?**

<br>

**SLIDE**: conditions matter
:::

    

## What is Policy? {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

<br>

"A definite course or method of action selected (as by a government, institution, group or individual) from among alternatives and [**in the light of given conditions**]{style="color:blue;"} to guide and usually determine present and future decisions..." (Webster's Third International Dictionary).

::: notes

3) A policy, by definition, must be adapted to the important "conditions" of the problem

- In other words, the quality of your plan also DEPENDS on how well you've adapted it to the conditions on the ground.

- No one-size-fits-all policy solutions are appropriate here.

<br>

This seems like another piece of advice rather than a simple definition

- But I love this advice too so let's keep it!


<br>

THIS is the danger of groups tied or committed to a specific ideology.

- Both cutting regulations and adding new ones are powerful options for influencing behavior, BUT

- It is the context of the problem that should guide your policy design, not vice versa!

- If you know the policy answer before you hear the problem you are not taking it seriously

<br>

**SLIDE**: stakeholders matter
:::



## What is Policy? {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

<br>

"A definite course or method of action selected (as by a government, institution, group or individual) from among alternatives and in the light of given conditions [**to guide and usually determine present and future decisions**]{style="color:blue;"}..." (Webster's Third International Dictionary).

::: notes

4) A policy, by definition, "guide[s]" or "determine[s]" future behavior by stakeholders

- Stakeholders e.g. the people involved in the problem

<br>

And now we're back to the definition rather than the advice

- If your rule is sufficiently clear then it will move behavior now AND guide future behavior too!

## {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

### Problem-solving in a community requires policy, but policymaking has pre-requisites!


![](Images/02-1-Munger_Fig2-3.png){style="display: block; margin: 0 auto"}

::: notes

Just because you now accept that a problem is serious and needs policy to address it, doesn't mean the community is on board!

- In Figure 2.3 Munger lays out his "three stages of policy choice"

- aka "Deciding How to Decide"

<br>

In essence, Munger's three steps are:

1. Convince the community that there is a problem,

2. Convince the community that it should be addressed collectively, and

3. Convince the community of how the specific policy should be adopted

<br>

Fundamentally, this figure is a reminder for ALL policymakers: **BEFORE you try to solve ANY problem, you MUST make a number of convincing arguments**

<br>

**SLIDE**: For our purposes, I'm going to boil these down to two distinct steps I'm describing as the pre-requisites of policy

:::



## {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

::: {.r-fit-text}
**Policymaking Pre-Requisites**

<br>

You must convince the community that:

1. We have a public problem, and

2. We require a collective decision to solve it
:::

::: notes

Each pre-requisite is a distinct argument that you have to successfully make before moving to any actual policy-design

<br>

In other words, before we can debate rules, new taxes, subsidies or anything else you first must succeed in convincing the community that collective action is needed.

- This is NOT an easy step, but the better you do this the easier the rest of the process becomes.

<br>

Let's start with the first of these

- **SLIDE**: What does it mean to argue that we have a public problem?

:::

## {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png"}

::: {.r-fit-text}
**Munger's (2000) Three "Wisdoms"**

1. **Markets**

2. Politics

3. Experts
:::

![](Images/03_1-Market-economies.webp){.absolute right=0 bottom=75 width="600"}

::: notes

**What would it mean to adopt the markets as your primary "wisdom" for policymaking?**

- **In other words, how might a markets-focus be used to solve environmental problems?**

<br>

Preference for allocating resources AND solving problems using systems of private exchange. 

- Concerned primarily with process, less so with outcomes

- Preference for non-interventionist style policies wherever possible

- Rules only to keep that market well functioning (contract enforcement, etc)

<br>

**What would a market-based solution to our magical fishery resource look like?**

- **How many fishers? Who fishes? What about enforcement?**

<br>

**According to the chapter, what are the pros and cons of prioritizing a markets focus over the others?**

Pros: 

- Most efficient by definition (most bang for the resource buck)

<br>

Cons - Market failures such as:

1) Monopolies (e.g. antitrust), 

2) Externalities (e.g. pollution), 

3) Under supply of public goods (e.g. free-riding), and 

4) Information problems (e.g. drug safety); Reduces all problems to maximization of use issues

## {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png"}

::: {.r-fit-text}
**Munger's (2000) Three "Wisdoms"**

1. Markets

2. **Politics**

3. Experts
:::

![](Images/03_1-politics.jpg){.absolute right=0 bottom=125 width="600"}

::: notes

**What would it mean to adopt politics as your primary "wisdom" for policymaking?**

- **In other words, how might a politics-focus prefer we solve environmental problems?**

<br>

Preference for allocating resources AND solving problems emphasizing the role of institutions and citizen involvement in the process. 

- Institutions designed to coordinate and facilitate collective action 

- Typically concerned about process and outcomes 

<br>

**What would a politics-based solution to our magical fishery resource look like?**

- **How many fishers? Who fishes? What about enforcement?**

<br>

**According to the chapter, what are the pros and cons of prioritizing a politics focus over the others?**

Pros: 

- Can be done to maximize participation; 

<br>

Cons: 

- Can be very slow; 

- Can be very messy; 

- Often has trouble with long time horizon problems

:::



## {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png"}

::: {.r-fit-text}
**Munger's (2000) Three "Wisdoms"**

1. Markets

2. Politics

3. **Experts**
:::

![](Images/03_1-social_science.png){.absolute right=0 bottom=125 width="600"}

::: notes

**What would it mean to adopt expertise as your primary "wisdom" for policymaking?**

- **In other words, how might an experts-based focus prefer we solve environmental problems?**

<br>

Preference for allocating resources AND solving problems emphasizing deeper knowledge of the systems involved. 

- "someone who has the goal of improving the functioning of politics or markets" (31).

- Those systems can be economic, political or scientific.

<br>

**What would an expert driven solution to our magical fishery resource look like?**

- **How many fishers? Who fishes? What about enforcement?**

<br>

**According to the chapter, what are the pros and cons of prioritizing a politics focus over the others?**

Pros: 

- Hopefully relies on transparent and verifiable knowledge; 

- Plans built on expertise and designed with ongoing evaluation

<br>

Cons: 

- May discourage wide participation; 

- May privilege some uses/solutions over others; 

- May lead to inequitable outcomes depending on "who" the experts are

<br>
